sites.name: Place de la Comédie
sites.description: This vast oval plaza is the beating heart of Montpellier and one of the largest pedestrian areas in Europe. Dominated by the elegant Three Graces fountain and surrounded by beautiful 19th-century buildings including the Opéra Comédie, it's filled with cafés, street performers, and constant activity. The square connects to the Esplanade Charles de Gaulle and serves as the city's primary meeting point.
sites.seasonal_notes: Lively throughout the year. Summer evenings feature outdoor dining and performances. Christmas markets and decorations make it magical in December.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Numerous restaurants around the square may require reservations, especially during peak tourist season.

sites.name: Promenade du Peyrou
sites.description: This magnificent royal square features a statue of Louis XIV on horseback, the elegant Water Castle (Château d'Eau) and an 18th-century aqueduct. The elevated esplanade offers panoramic views of Montpellier and the surrounding landscape extending to the Mediterranean on clear days. The park is bordered by the monumental Arc de Triomphe (Porte du Peyrou).
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautiful year-round. Water markets on Sundays. The aqueduct is illuminated at night. Sunset views are particularly stunning in summer.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Water tower can be visited during limited hours as part of guided tours.

sites.name: Musée Fabre
sites.description: One of France's richest fine art museums houses an exceptional collection spanning from the Renaissance to contemporary art. Highlights include masterpieces by Delacroix, Courbet, Bazille, and a significant collection of works by Pierre Soulages. The museum, founded in 1825, underwent a major renovation in 2007 and now offers 9,200 square meters of exhibition space.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with seasonal exhibitions. Less crowded on weekday mornings. Air-conditioned refuge during summer heat.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required for general admission. Free entry on the first Sunday of each month. Audio guides available in multiple languages.

sites.name: Cathédrale Saint-Pierre
sites.description: This imposing Gothic cathedral dates from 1364 and features a distinctive porch with two massive cylindrical pillars creating a dramatic entrance. The interior houses valuable paintings and an impressive organ. The cathedral miraculously survived the Wars of Religion and stands adjacent to the historic Faculty of Medicine.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautiful lighting in mornings when sun illuminates the stained glass windows. Special services during Easter and Christmas. More peaceful during weekday visits.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Respect quiet during religious services. Occasionally closed for weddings or ceremonies.

sites.name: Jardin des Plantes
sites.description: The oldest botanical garden in France (founded in 1593) served as a model for all others in the country. Originally established for medical students to study medicinal plants, it now houses more than 2,500 plant species, including a historic greenhouse, centuries-old trees, and Mediterranean collections. The garden retains its charming historic layout with formalized beds and winding paths.
sites.seasonal_notes: Spring brings spectacular blooms. Summer offers shade under ancient trees. The greenhouse provides interest during winter months. Closed during periods of high wind.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Occasional guided tours available through the University of Montpellier.

sites.name: Quartier de l'Écusson
sites.description: The historic heart of Montpellier takes its name ('shield') from its medieval shield-like shape. This pedestrianized center is a maze of narrow winding streets, elegant mansions with hidden courtyards, small squares, and independent shops. Many buildings date from the 17th and 18th centuries when Montpellier was a major center of learning and commerce.
sites.seasonal_notes: Enjoyable year-round. Milder temperatures in spring and fall make exploration more comfortable. Many shops close on Sundays, but restaurants remain open.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for self-guided walking. Tourist office offers guided walking tours several times weekly (reservation recommended).

sites.name: Faculté de Médecine
sites.description: Founded in 1220, this is the world's oldest medical school still in operation. The historic building includes the spectacular anatomy amphitheater and houses a museum of medical history with anatomical collections, ancient instruments, and herbariums. The school has trained physicians for over 800 years and counts Nostradamus among its famous alumni.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open for guided tours only. Tours run year-round but may be limited during university examination periods. The courtyard can be viewed without a tour.
sites.booking_tips: Advance booking required for guided tours, which are offered in French and English on specific days only.

sites.name: Aqueduc Saint-Clément
sites.description: This impressive 18th-century aqueduct was built between 1753 and 1765 to bring water from the Saint-Clément spring to the Promenade du Peyrou. The most spectacular section, Les Arceaux, features two tiers of elegant arches rising 22 meters high and stretching for 800 meters through a modern neighborhood, creating a striking juxtaposition of ancient and contemporary.
sites.seasonal_notes: Accessible year-round. The stone is particularly golden in late afternoon sunlight. A farmers market is held beneath the arches on Tuesday and Saturday mornings.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Can be viewed from multiple angles by walking along Avenue François Delmas.

sites.name: Marché du Lez
sites.description: This vibrant space in a former industrial area combines vintage markets, food halls, designer boutiques, and co-working spaces. The renovated warehouses now host restaurants with outdoor terraces, weekend events, regular night markets, and pop-up shops, making it a creative hub for both locals and visitors seeking an alternative side of Montpellier.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with different operations for various venues. Summer brings outdoor concerts and events. The covered food hall operates regardless of weather.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for general access. Reservations recommended for restaurants, especially on weekends and event nights.

sites.name: MOCO Hôtel des Collections
sites.description: Opened in 2019 in a beautifully renovated 18th-century mansion, this contemporary art center doesn't have a permanent collection but instead hosts rotating exhibitions of international private and public collections. The museum forms part of Montpellier's ambitious MOCO ecosystem that includes the Panacée art center and the regional fine arts school.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round except Mondays. Exhibitions typically change three times yearly. The garden courtyard provides a pleasant setting in good weather.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Free guided tours available on weekends (check schedule on site).

sites.name: Odysseum
sites.description: This large modern complex combines shopping, dining, and entertainment facilities on the eastern edge of the city. Attractions include an aquarium (Planet Ocean), planetarium, ice rink, bowling alley, multiplex cinema, and a miniature golf course alongside numerous shops and restaurants. It's easily accessible by tram from the city center.
sites.seasonal_notes: Most attractions operate year-round. More crowded during school holidays and weekends. Air-conditioned refuge during summer heat.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for general access. Individual attractions may require tickets or reservations. Planet Ocean aquarium offers discounted tickets when purchased online.

sites.name: Plage du Grand Travers
sites.description: The closest major beach to Montpellier offers miles of fine sand and Mediterranean shoreline just 10km from the city center. The beach is well-maintained with clear waters that have consistently earned Blue Flag status. The expansive shoreline means it's possible to find less crowded spots even in high season. Nearby La Grande-Motte offers additional services and dining options.
sites.seasonal_notes: Summer (June-September) is peak season with lifeguards on duty. Spring and fall offer pleasant temperatures with fewer crowds. Winter walks can be refreshingly wild and atmospheric.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Accessible by car (paid parking in summer) or by seasonal shuttle bus from Montpellier. Arrive early in summer to secure parking.

sites.name: Parc Zoologique de Montpellier
sites.description: One of the largest zoological parks in France covers 80 hectares on a hill north of the city. The landscaped park houses around 140 species in spacious, naturalistic enclosures designed to represent different world ecosystems. The park focuses on conservation efforts and maintains a notable Amazon greenhouse and African plain with giraffes and rhinoceros.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round except certain holidays. Animals are most active in morning and late afternoon. Some sections may close during extreme weather conditions.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Free entry on the first Sunday of each month from October to March. Plan for substantial walking.

sites.name: Château de Flaugergues
sites.description: This elegant 'folly' (country mansion) built in the 18th century represents the height of aristocratic architecture surrounded by French and English gardens. The estate includes meticulously preserved period furnishings, a working vineyard producing award-winning wines, and botanical gardens featuring a bamboo plantation and Mediterranean species.
sites.seasonal_notes: Gardens are particularly beautiful in spring. The château hosts summer jazz concerts in the gardens. Wine tastings available year-round.
sites.booking_tips: Tours of the château interior require advance booking. Gardens can be visited independently. Combined tickets available for house, gardens, and wine tasting.

sites.name: Pic Saint-Loup
sites.description: This distinctive limestone peak rises dramatically to 658 meters from the surrounding vineyards and garrigue landscape 20km north of Montpellier. The mountain offers hiking trails with panoramic views extending from the Mediterranean to the Cévennes mountains. The area is also known for producing exceptional wines under the Pic Saint-Loup appellation.
sites.seasonal_notes: Spring and fall offer ideal hiking conditions. Summer hiking should be early morning only due to extreme heat. Winter ascents possible on clear days but can be windy at the summit.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Access by car from Montpellier takes approximately 40 minutes. Several marked trails of varying difficulty available.

sites.name: Esplanade de l'Europe
sites.description: This expansive pedestrian promenade connects Place de la Comédie with the Corum concert hall and features tree-lined walkways, fountains, and open spaces for relaxation. The upper level offers views over the city while the lower level includes a popular children's playground and spaces often used for cultural events, exhibitions, and seasonal markets.
sites.seasonal_notes: The tree canopy provides welcome shade during summer. Winter features festive decorations and occasional special markets. The area hosts parts of summer festivals and outdoor cinema events.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Adjacent to the tourist office for convenient information access.

sites.name: Le Corum
sites.description: This striking pink marble building designed by Claude Vasconi houses Montpellier's opera house (Opéra Berlioz), a concert hall (Salle Pasteur), and a major conference center. The rooftop terrace is publicly accessible and offers spectacular panoramic views of the city, the Mediterranean Sea, and the surrounding mountains.
sites.seasonal_notes: Performance schedule varies throughout the year. The rooftop terrace is particularly pleasant at sunset. The building hosts the international Radio France festival each July.
sites.booking_tips: Performances require advance tickets. The rooftop terrace can be visited freely during opening hours without booking.

sites.name: Halles Castellane
sites.description: This vibrant covered market in the heart of the historic center offers a authentic taste of local gastronomy with vendors selling fresh produce, meats, cheeses, seafood, and prepared foods. The recently renovated hall preserves its traditional market atmosphere while incorporating modern amenities, and is surrounded by cafés that spill onto the adjacent square.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open Tuesday to Sunday mornings, closing around 2pm. Sunday mornings are particularly lively but crowded. Seasonal local produce changes throughout the year.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Come before noon for the best selection and atmosphere. Several vendors offer lunch options for on-site consumption.

sites.name: Antigone District
sites.description: This distinctive neoclassical neighborhood was designed by Catalan architect Ricardo Bofill in the 1970s and 80s as an extension of Montpellier's historic center. The monumental district features grand boulevards, classical-inspired facades, dramatic colonnades, and geometric public spaces arranged on a symmetrical axis leading to the River Lez.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open for exploration year-round. The light-colored stone is particularly beautiful in afternoon sunlight. The large open plazas can be very hot in summer without much shade.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for self-guided walking. The tourist office occasionally offers architectural tours that include this district.

sites.name: MO.CO.Panacée
sites.description: Housed in a former 16th-century medical college, this cutting-edge contemporary art center features rotating exhibitions of experimental works by emerging international artists. The complex includes multiple exhibition spaces, a café with a pleasant courtyard, and regularly hosts workshops, performances, and public discussions as part of Montpellier's contemporary art ecosystem.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round except Mondays. Exhibitions typically change several times per year. The courtyard café is especially pleasant in warm weather.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Free guided tours available on weekends (check schedule). Student curators often provide additional insights about exhibitions.

sites.name: Porte du Peyrou
sites.description: This triumphal arch was built between 1691 and 1693 to honor Louis XIV and marks the entrance to the royal square Promenade du Peyrou. Designed to resemble the Porte Saint-Denis in Paris, the monument features military trophies, bas-reliefs depicting the king's victories, and medallions representing the annexed territories of Languedoc to the French kingdom.
sites.seasonal_notes: Accessible year-round. The golden stone is particularly beautiful in morning light. The arch is illuminated at night creating dramatic photo opportunities.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. The interior is not accessible, but visitors can walk through the archway that connects the medieval city to the Peyrou promenade.

neighborhoods.name: Écusson
neighborhoods.character: The medieval heart of Montpellier with a maze of narrow winding streets, elegant squares, and grand mansions, offering a vibrant blend of historical architecture, upscale shopping, café culture, and student life in a largely pedestrianized environment.

location.description: The historic core of Montpellier, bordered by boulevards that follow the outline of the city's medieval walls (which gave the area its shield-like 'écusson' shape), with Place de la Comédie as its southeastern entrance.

history.overview: Founded in the 10th century and developed primarily between the 12th and 16th centuries when Montpellier was a major center of trade and learning. The district's layout preserves the medieval street pattern while featuring grand architecture from the 17th and 18th centuries when wealthy merchants built private mansions.
history.significance: Represents Montpellier's golden age as a Mediterranean trade hub and intellectual center, particularly known for its medical school, which remains the oldest active medical faculty in the Western world.
notable_events: Establishment of the University of Montpellier's medical school in 1220
Construction of the majority of the city's grand hôtels particuliers in the 17th and 18th centuries
Pedestrianization of much of the historic center in the 1980s and 90s

transit: Tram lines 1, 2, and 4 serve the edges of the district
Limited vehicle access (primarily residents and deliveries)
Multiple public parking garages surround the perimeter
practical_info.safety: Very safe area with high foot traffic and good lighting throughout. Standard precautions apply in late evening hours.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Morning for quiet exploration of historic sites, evenings for dining and vibrant atmosphere.
practical_info.walkability: Extremely walkable with pedestrianized streets, though narrow cobblestone passages can be challenging with mobility issues.

attractions.name: Place de la Comédie
attractions.description: Montpellier's iconic central plaza, nicknamed 'l'Oeuf' (the Egg) due to its original oval shape, featuring the Three Graces fountain, surrounded by elegant 19th-century buildings and bustling cafés.
attractions.appeal: The vibrant heart of city life and a perfect spot for people-watching from café terraces.

attractions.name: Promenade du Peyrou
attractions.description: Majestic 17th-century esplanade featuring a statue of Louis XIV, water tower (Château d'Eau), and spectacular views extending to the Mediterranean on clear days.
attractions.appeal: The most elegant public space in Montpellier with a regal atmosphere and panoramic vistas.

attractions.name: Hôtels Particuliers
attractions.description: Grand private mansions built by wealthy merchants and nobles between the 17th and 19th centuries, featuring hidden courtyards and elaborate staircases accessible through guided tours or during heritage days.
attractions.appeal: Architectural treasures revealing the private luxury behind austere street facades.

dining.name: La Diligence
dining.known_for: Classic regional cuisine in a 17th-century vaulted setting

dining.name: Le Petit Jardin
dining.known_for: Garden dining in a historic courtyard setting

dining.name: Terminal #1
dining.known_for: Innovative small plates and natural wines

activities.name: Hidden Courtyards Tour
activities.description: Explore the normally inaccessible interior courtyards of grand mansions with an expert guide explaining the history and architectural details.

activities.name: Market Shopping at Les Halles Castellane
activities.description: Visit the covered market to sample regional specialties, local wines, and fresh seafood from Mediterranean coast.

stay_here_if: You want to be in the historic heart of the city with attractions at your doorstep
You appreciate historic architecture and atmosphere
You enjoy vibrant street life, café culture, and dining options
avoid_if: You're sensitive to noise (parts can be lively until late, especially in summer)
You require easy vehicle access or parking
You prefer modern accommodations with spacious rooms
insider_tips: Visit the Faculty of Medicine's historic anatomy theater by booking a guided tour in advance – it's the oldest medical school still in operation in the Western world.
Many hidden courtyards of private mansions are accessible during European Heritage Days (Journées du Patrimoine) in September.
For the best photos of the aqueduct at Les Arceaux, visit in the late afternoon when the golden light illuminates the stone arches.

neighborhoods.name: Antigone
neighborhoods.character: A monumental neoclassical district designed in the 1970s and 80s by Catalan architect Ricardo Bofill, featuring grand boulevards, geometric symmetry, and imposing buildings with classical elements that create a dramatic contrast to the medieval center.

location.description: Located directly east of the historic center, extending from Place de la Comédie to the Lez River in a carefully planned linear layout with a central axis.

history.overview: Created in the late 1970s and 1980s on the site of former military barracks as Montpellier's first major urban expansion since the 19th century, designed as a cohesive architectural statement that would extend the city eastward toward the Lez River.
history.significance: Represents Montpellier's ambitious urban development under Mayor Georges Frêche and showcases postmodern architectural principles with a Mediterranean classical influence.
notable_events: Selection of Ricardo Bofill as master architect in 1977
Establishment of the Hôtel de Région (Regional Government Headquarters) as architectural centerpiece

transit: Tram lines 1 and 4 run along the southern edge
Tram line 4 runs through Place du Nombre d'Or
Multiple bus routes
Bicycle-friendly with wide boulevards
practical_info.safety: Very safe area with wide open spaces and good visibility. Well-lit at night with moderate foot traffic.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Late afternoon when the sunlight enhances the warm tones of the buildings.
practical_info.walkability: Extremely walkable with wide boulevards, open squares, and flat terrain throughout.

best_for: Those seeking contrast to medieval center

attractions.name: Place du Nombre d'Or
attractions.description: Central plaza in the heart of Antigone featuring Bofill's signature neoclassical elements, colonnades, and a geometric layout based on the golden ratio.
attractions.appeal: The defining space of the district showcasing the architect's vision of contemporary classicism.

attractions.name: Regional Government Headquarters
attractions.description: Monumental administrative complex serving as the seat of the Occitanie regional government, featuring dramatic classical elements at a grand scale.
attractions.appeal: The architectural centerpiece of Antigone demonstrating the district's political importance.

attractions.name: Antigone Linear Axis
attractions.description: The central pedestrian boulevard stretching from Place de la Comédie to the Lez River, featuring a carefully designed sequence of public spaces and symmetrical buildings.
attractions.appeal: A masterclass in planned urban design with perfect symmetry and classical proportions.

dining.name: La Tamarillos
dining.known_for: Creative seasonal dishes in a modern setting

dining.name: Les Bains
dining.known_for: Classic dishes in historic bathhouse building

activities.name: Architectural Walking Tour
activities.description: Follow the central axis from west to east, observing how the spaces unfold according to Bofill's master plan and classical references.

activities.name: Olympic Swimming Pool
activities.description: Visit or swim in the architecturally significant Olympic pool facility designed as part of the original Antigone plan.

stay_here_if: You want a central but quieter alternative to the historic center
avoid_if: You prefer bustling street life and café culture
You dislike planned developments with uniform architectural style
insider_tips: Visit during the late afternoon golden hour when the warm Mediterranean light brings out the best in the ochre-colored facades.
The central reflecting pool often has its water drained – check local events as it's sometimes used for performances and temporary installations.
For the best panoramic view of Antigone's symmetrical layout, visit the upper floors of the Polygone shopping center at the western entrance.

neighborhoods.name: Port Marianne
neighborhoods.character: Montpellier's showcase of contemporary architecture and urban planning, featuring striking modern buildings by international architects, organized around the landscaped banks of the Lez River with a blend of residential, commercial, and leisure spaces.

location.description: Located in eastern Montpellier beyond Antigone, extending along both banks of the Lez River and developing eastward with numerous sub-neighborhoods still under construction.

history.overview: Developed primarily since the 1990s as Montpellier's eastward expansion, Port Marianne represents the city's ambition to become a showcase for contemporary architecture and sustainable urban development.
history.significance: Embodies Montpellier's transformation from a historic regional center to a forward-looking Mediterranean metropolis emphasizing architectural innovation and quality of life.
notable_events: Adoption of the Port Marianne masterplan in the 1990s
Construction of Jean Nouvel's iconic City Hall in 2011
Ongoing development of multiple districts, each with distinctive architectural identity

transit: Tram lines 1, 3, and 4 serve different areas of the district
Multiple bus routes
Extensive bicycle path network
Good vehicle access with numerous parking facilities
practical_info.safety: Very safe area with good lighting, modern infrastructure, and mixed-use development providing activity throughout the day and evening.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Afternoons and early evenings when the contemporary architecture catches the light and riverside areas are lively.
practical_info.walkability: Generally walkable but somewhat spread out; the tram or bicycles are useful for covering the entire district.

attractions.name: Hôtel de Ville (City Hall)
attractions.description: Striking blue cube-shaped building designed by Jean Nouvel, featuring a dramatic cantilever and innovative sustainable design elements including natural ventilation and solar shading.
attractions.appeal: Iconic example of contemporary civic architecture that has become a symbol of modern Montpellier.

attractions.name: Bassin Jacques Cœur
attractions.description: Attractive residential area centered around an artificial basin connected to the Lez River, with apartments and restaurants lining the waterfront promenades.
attractions.appeal: Mediterranean-inspired waterfront living creating a distinct atmosphere compared to the historic center.

attractions.name: Lez River Banks
attractions.description: Landscaped pedestrian and cycling paths along the river, connecting various parts of the district with green spaces and leisure areas.
attractions.appeal: Natural corridor providing recreational space and a scenic spine through the modern developments.

dining.name: Le Nuage
dining.known_for: Elegant dining in Philippe Starck's cloud-shaped building

dining.name: Terminal #2
dining.known_for: Creative small plates and extensive wine selection

dining.name: Café de la Panacée
dining.known_for: Seasonal creative cuisine in artistic setting

activities.name: Contemporary Architecture Tour
activities.description: Discover signature buildings by famous architects including Jean Nouvel, Zaha Hadid, Philippe Starck, and local firms scattered throughout the district.

activities.name: Lez River Activities
activities.description: Walking, running, cycling, and occasional water sports along the landscaped river corridor that forms the spine of Port Marianne.

stay_here_if: You appreciate contemporary architecture and modern amenities
You prefer spacious, newly developed areas with good transportation
You enjoy waterfront environments and outdoor activities
avoid_if: You're primarily interested in historic atmosphere
You prefer the density and character of traditional urban centers
You dislike areas still under development with ongoing construction
insider_tips: The upper floors of the City Hall are open to the public on European Heritage Days (Journées du Patrimoine) in September, offering rare views from its dramatic cantilevered section.
Check the schedule for the summer floating cinema which occasionally shows films on a screen in the Bassin Jacques Cœur with viewers watching from the banks.
The RBC Design Center has a publicly accessible rooftop with excellent views of the district and a small café that's rarely crowded.

neighborhoods.name: Les Arceaux
neighborhoods.character: A charming residential neighborhood just west of the historic center, characterized by the dramatic 18th-century aqueduct that runs through it, tree-lined avenues, a vibrant twice-weekly market, and a laid-back local atmosphere popular with families and academics.

location.description: Located immediately west of the historic center, extending from the Peyrou royal promenade toward Parc Montcalm, named after the impressive aqueduct arches that define the area.

history.overview: Developed primarily in the 19th and early 20th centuries around the impressive Saint-Clément Aqueduct, built between 1753-1766 to bring water to the Peyrou water tower and supply the growing city.
history.significance: Represents both an engineering achievement of the Enlightenment period and the expansion of Montpellier beyond its medieval walls into elegant residential areas.
notable_events: Construction of the Saint-Clément Aqueduct in the mid-18th century
Development as a desirable residential area in the 19th century
Establishment of the farmers market beneath the arches, now one of the city's most beloved markets

transit: Tram line 3 runs along the southern edge
Multiple bus routes connect to the city center
Bicycle-friendly neighborhood with good infrastructure
10-15 minute walk to Place de la Comédie
practical_info.safety: Very safe residential area with strong community feeling. Well-lit main streets and good pedestrian infrastructure.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Tuesday and Saturday mornings for the market, late afternoon for photography of the aqueduct.
practical_info.walkability: Highly walkable neighborhood with pleasant streets, though with some hills leading west from the center.

attractions.name: Arceaux Saint-Clément
attractions.description: Impressive 18th-century aqueduct featuring two tiers of elegant arches stretching over 800 meters through the neighborhood, originally built to supply water to the city center.
attractions.appeal: Dramatic architectural feature that creates a unique backdrop for daily life and the neighborhood market.

attractions.name: Marché des Arceaux
attractions.description: Bustling twice-weekly market (Tuesdays and Saturdays) set beneath the arches of the aqueduct, featuring local producers, organic products, and regional specialties.
attractions.appeal: One of Montpellier's most atmospheric markets, beloved by locals and set in a spectacular historic setting.

attractions.name: Jardin des Plantes
attractions.description: Founded in 1593, France's oldest botanical garden sits at the northeastern edge of the neighborhood, featuring medicinal plants, historic greenhouses, and peaceful walking paths.
attractions.appeal: Historic scientific garden that offers a tranquil green retreat with educational value.

dining.name: L'Artichaut
dining.known_for: Innovative plant-based cuisine using market ingredients

dining.name: Café de la Mer
dining.known_for: Fresh market-inspired dishes with local wines

dining.name: Le Petit Jardin
dining.known_for: Garden dining in historic setting near Peyrou

activities.name: Market Shopping and Picnic
activities.description: Shop for local specialties at the farmers market and enjoy a picnic in the nearby Peyrou gardens with panoramic views over the city.

activities.name: Aqueduct Photography Walk
activities.description: Follow the course of the aqueduct from the Peyrou water tower through Les Arceaux, capturing the changing perspectives and light on the ancient stone arches.

stay_here_if: You want a local residential experience close to the historic center
You enjoy market culture and food shopping
You prefer quieter neighborhoods with character
avoid_if: You want to be in the center of nightlife and tourist activities
You have limited mobility (some streets have inclines)
insider_tips: Arrive at the Arceaux market before 9am on Saturday for the best selection and to beat the crowds, particularly in summer.
The section of the aqueduct near Rue Pitot offers the most dramatic views and photo opportunities, especially in late afternoon light.
The small Place Saint-Côme at the edge of the district has several good wine bars where locals gather on warm evenings.

neighborhoods.name: Beaux-Arts
neighborhoods.character: A bohemian, artistic neighborhood with a village-like atmosphere, popular with students and creative professionals, offering a mix of traditional architecture, small independent shops, casual dining, and a youthful energy with strong community spirit.

location.description: Located north of the historic center between the university faculties and the Lez River, developed primarily as a residential extension in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

history.overview: Originally developed in the late 19th century as Montpellier expanded beyond its medieval core, the neighborhood has evolved from a working-class area to a bohemian district popular with students, artists, and academics from the nearby university.
history.significance: Represents the preservation of a village-like community within the urban context, maintaining a distinct identity and local culture despite its central location.
notable_events: Development as a primarily residential district in the late 19th century
Growth of artistic community in the post-war period
Urban renewal and gentrification since the 1990s while maintaining its bohemian character

transit: Tram line 2 serves the eastern edge
Multiple bus routes
Bicycle-friendly with good infrastructure
15-minute walk to Place de la Comédie
practical_info.safety: Very safe neighborhood with strong community presence. Normal precautions apply at night.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Early evenings when local life is most vibrant, particularly Thursday and Friday.
practical_info.walkability: Highly walkable neighborhood with pleasant streets and pedestrian-friendly atmosphere.

attractions.name: Place des Beaux-Arts
attractions.description: The heart of the neighborhood featuring a small fountain, surrounded by cafés, restaurants, and shops that create a focal point for community life.
attractions.appeal: Authentic local gathering place with vibrant atmosphere, particularly in evenings.

attractions.name: Marché du Mercredi
attractions.description: Wednesday street market along Avenue Bouisson-Bertrand offering fresh produce, local products, and atmosphere.
attractions.appeal: Authentic neighborhood commerce where locals do their weekly shopping.

attractions.name: Street Art Tour
attractions.description: The neighborhood features numerous murals and street art installations, some commissioned and others spontaneous, reflecting its creative character.
attractions.appeal: Open-air gallery that changes regularly with new works appearing throughout the area.

dining.atmosphere: Casual and lively with student vibe

dining.known_for: Market-fresh seasonal dishes with regional influence

dining.name: Broc Café

dining.atmosphere: Cozy with vintage décor and artistic clientele

activities.name: Evening Bar Hopping
activities.description: Explore the neighborhood's diverse collection of wine bars, craft beer spots, and casual hangouts popular with local students and creatives.

activities.name: Independent Shopping
activities.description: Discover small independent shops selling everything from vintage clothing to handmade jewelry, local art, and unique gifts.

stay_here_if: You want to experience local Montpellier life away from tourist areas
You enjoy bohemian, artistic neighborhoods with character
You're looking for budget-friendly dining and nightlife options
avoid_if: You prefer luxury accommodations and upscale environments
You want immediate access to major tourist attractions
You're sensitive to typical urban noise including student revelry
insider_tips: Many local shops and restaurants close in August when owners take vacation, but the neighborhood comes alive for the 'Estivales' summer evening markets on Thursdays.
The tiny Bar à Vins de la Canourgue has an excellent selection of local wines by the glass and is a favorite meeting spot for local artists and academics.
Several buildings have interesting interior courtyards that aren't visible from the street - look for open doors during the day to peek inside.

neighborhoods.name: Gambetta
neighborhoods.character: A diverse, multicultural neighborhood with North African influences, offering authentic markets, international food shops, affordable dining, and a vibrant community atmosphere that provides a genuine contrast to the more tourist-oriented areas of Montpellier.

location.description: Located west of the historic center past Les Arceaux, developed along Cours Gambetta as a working-class area that has become one of the city's most culturally diverse districts.

history.overview: Developed primarily in the late 19th and early 20th centuries as a working-class district, the area has evolved into a multicultural neighborhood with significant North African and Mediterranean immigration since the 1960s and 1970s.
history.significance: Represents Montpellier's cultural diversity and immigrant heritage, providing authentic cultural experiences beyond the more polished historic center.
notable_events: Development as working-class housing during industrial expansion
Significant North African immigration from the 1960s onwards
Controversial relocation of the main market from Place Salengro in the early 2000s
Recent gentrification while maintaining multicultural character

transit: Tram line 3 runs through the district
Multiple bus routes
Bicycle-friendly with dedicated lanes on main roads
15-20 minute walk to Place de la Comédie
practical_info.safety: Generally safe but exercise normal urban precautions, particularly at night. Some areas have a rougher reputation but are typically fine during daylight hours.
practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Mornings for market activity, particularly at Plan Cabanes.
practical_info.walkability: Very walkable neighborhood with flat terrain and pedestrian-friendly streets.

attractions.name: Marché du Plan Cabanes
attractions.description: Vibrant open-air market featuring North African and Mediterranean produce, spices, textiles, and goods that reflect the district's diverse population.
attractions.appeal: Authentic cultural experience with sights, sounds, and flavors rarely found in more tourist-oriented areas.

attractions.name: International Food Shops
attractions.description: Concentrated along Cours Gambetta and surrounding streets, numerous shops selling ingredients, spices, pastries, and products from North Africa, Middle East, and beyond.
attractions.appeal: Culinary exploration opportunities and authentic shopping experience.

attractions.name: Parc de la Guirlande
attractions.description: Small but vital green space serving as community gathering place, particularly for families, with playground, benches, and occasional events.
attractions.appeal: Glimpse of everyday local life in a multicultural setting.

dining.name: Chez Karim
dining.known_for: Authentic tagines and couscous in generous portions

dining.name: Le Sphinx
dining.known_for: Mezze platters and grilled meats with fresh bread

dining.name: La Khaima
dining.known_for: Rare opportunity to try Mauritanian cuisine with communal dining

activities.name: Culinary Exploration
activities.description: Spend a morning exploring the specialty food shops, bakeries, and market stalls sampling pastries, olives, spices, and other delicacies from different cultures.

activities.name: Community Events
activities.description: Check local postings for community festivals, music events, and cultural celebrations that frequently take place in the neighborhood's public spaces.

stay_here_if: You want an authentic, non-touristy neighborhood experience
You're interested in multicultural environments and global cuisines
You're a budget-conscious traveler looking for affordable accommodation
avoid_if: You're uncomfortable in working-class, diverse urban settings
You want convenient access to main tourist attractions
insider_tips: The best time to visit the Plan Cabanes market is Tuesday morning when it's busy but not overcrowded and selection is best.
Look for the small patisseries selling North African sweets like makroud and baklava – most are family businesses using traditional recipes.
Several buildings showcase interesting street art, particularly along Rue du Faubourg Figuerolles leading into the adjacent Figuerolles district.

City of Roman monuments, Van Gogh heritage, and gateway to the Camargue wetlands with wild horses and flamingos.

activities.name: Promenade du Peyrou
activities.description: Explore this magnificent royal square featuring a statue of Louis XIV, the elegant Water Castle (Château d'Eau), and the 18th-century Saint-Clément Aqueduct, all while enjoying panoramic views of the city extending to the Mediterranean on clear spring days.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring brings perfect mild temperatures and blooming trees to this iconic esplanade, with fewer tourists than summer months and clear visibility toward the sea.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required. The water tower can occasionally be visited during Heritage Days or special events, but the promenade is always accessible.

activities.name: Jardin des Plantes
activities.description: Visit France's oldest botanical garden (established 1593) when spring brings magnificent blooms to its historic collections of medicinal plants, Mediterranean species, and ancient trees.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring is spectacular here with flowering magnolias, rare medicinal plants, and Mediterranean collections bursting into bloom after winter dormancy.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required. Guided tours are occasionally available through the University of Montpellier's botany department, especially during spring plant festivals.

activities.name: Les Estivales Preview Events
activities.description: Catch the early season preview events of Montpellier's famous summer wine and food festival, with special tastings and cultural performances throughout the historic center.
activities.seasonal_notes: Late spring (May) sees the first of these popular events that showcase regional wines, local cuisine, and artisanal products before the full summer program begins.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required. Purchase tasting tickets on-site for wine sampling. Events typically occur in Place de la Comédie or Esplanade Charles de Gaulle.

activities.name: Pic Saint-Loup Hiking
activities.description: Trek to the summit of this iconic limestone peak just north of Montpellier, offering spectacular panoramic views across the vineyards to the Mediterranean Sea.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring offers ideal hiking conditions with moderate temperatures, wildflowers in bloom, and green landscapes before the summer heat and dryness arrive.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required, but organized tours are available through local outdoor companies. Drive 30 minutes from Montpellier to the trailhead at Cazevieille.

activities.name: Marché des Arceaux
activities.description: Experience one of Montpellier's largest and most picturesque markets, held twice weekly beneath the arches of the historic Saint-Clément Aqueduct, showcasing local spring produce, flowers, and artisanal products.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring brings abundant local asparagus, strawberries, cherries, and young goat cheeses from the Cévennes mountains to this vibrant market.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required. Visit Tuesday and Saturday mornings (7am-1:30pm), with Saturday being larger and more atmospheric. Arrive before 10am to avoid crowds.

activities.name: Fête de la Musique
activities.description: Join this nationwide celebration of music that transforms Montpellier's streets, squares, and parks into open-air concert venues featuring every genre from classical to electronic, jazz to world music.
activities.seasonal_notes: Held on June 21st (summer solstice), this festival marks the transition from spring to summer with hundreds of free performances throughout the city.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required. Pick up a program from the tourist office to plan your musical journey through different city quarters. The Ecusson district and Place de la Comédie host the largest performances.

activities.name: Palavas-les-Flots Beach
activities.description: Enjoy the first beach days of the year at this popular seaside resort just 12km from Montpellier, with wide sandy beaches and a traditional fishing port atmosphere.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring offers pleasant beach weather with fewer crowds than summer, warm enough for sunbathing and paddling by late May, with restaurants and facilities beginning their season.
activities.booking_tips: Take the direct 606 bus from Montpellier city center (Place de France) or cycle along the dedicated bike path along the Lez River to the coast.

activities.name: Wine Tasting in Pic Saint-Loup
activities.description: Visit vineyards in the prestigious Pic Saint-Loup appellation as vines burst into spring growth, tasting the region's distinguished reds and rosés in picturesque settings beneath the mountain.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring is beautiful in the vineyards with fresh foliage on the vines, wildflowers between rows, and the opportunity to taste recently bottled vintages from previous harvests.
activities.booking_tips: Book a guided wine tour from Montpellier or drive yourself to wineries like Château de Cazeneuve or Mas Bruguière, calling ahead to arrange tastings.

activities.name: Antigone Shopping and Architecture Tour
activities.description: Explore Montpellier's distinctive neoclassical district designed by architect Ricardo Bofill, featuring dramatic columns, pedestrian plazas, and monumental buildings along a perfectly symmetrical axis.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring sunshine brings out the warm tones in the district's distinctive limestone facades, while comfortable temperatures make it ideal for architectural appreciation.
activities.booking_tips: Self-guided tours are possible following the main axis from Place du Nombre d'Or to the River Lez. The tourist office offers guided architectural tours in multiple languages.

activities.name: Les Estivales de Montpellier
activities.description: Experience Montpellier's popular summer evening festival where the Esplanade Charles de Gaulle transforms into an open-air wine and food celebration every Friday, showcasing local producers, craftspeople, and musicians.
activities.seasonal_notes: This weekly summer event runs from June through early September, bringing locals and visitors together to enjoy Mediterranean evening ambiance with food, wine, and music.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required. Purchase a wine glass for around €5 that includes three tasting tickets. Additional tastings can be bought separately. Arrive before 8pm to secure seating.

activities.name: Radio France Festival
activities.description: Attend this prestigious classical music festival featuring world-class orchestras, soloists, and contemporary compositions in venues throughout Montpellier, with many performances in the stunning Le Corum concert hall.
activities.seasonal_notes: This July festival is one of France's most important classical music events, with air-conditioned venues providing a perfect escape from summer heat.
activities.booking_tips: Book tickets well in advance through the festival website or at Le Corum box office. Some outdoor concerts in historic courtyards are free but require reservations.

activities.name: Mediterranean Beaches
activities.description: Escape the city heat with a day trip to the beautiful Mediterranean beaches near Montpellier, including La Grande-Motte, Carnon, Palavas-les-Flots, or the more natural Espiguette Beach.
activities.seasonal_notes: Summer brings warm sea temperatures and full beach services to these coastal towns, all within 30 minutes of Montpellier by public transport.
activities.booking_tips: Take direct buses from the Place de France transport hub in Montpellier to various beaches. Arrive early (before 10am) to secure good spots, especially in July and August.

activities.name: Festivals d'Avignon Day Trip
activities.description: Visit the nearby city of Avignon during its world-famous theater festival when the entire walled city becomes a stage for hundreds of performances from traditional to experimental.
activities.seasonal_notes: This three-week July festival transforms Avignon into the theater capital of Europe, with performances in historic venues, streets, and improvised spaces throughout the city.
activities.booking_tips: Book main festival shows online in advance, but hundreds of 'Off' festival performances can be booked on the day. Take the direct train from Montpellier to Avignon (1 hour).

activities.name: Canoeing on the Hérault River
activities.description: Paddle down the crystal-clear Hérault River through spectacular limestone gorges, stopping to swim at natural pools beneath the medieval village of Saint-Guilhem-le-Désert.
activities.seasonal_notes: Summer is perfect for this refreshing activity, with warm water temperatures and the cool river providing respite from Mediterranean heat.
activities.booking_tips: Book canoe rentals in advance with companies in Saint-Guilhem-le-Désert or Gignac. Half-day and full-day trips are available with shuttle service back to your starting point.

activities.name: Nighttime Markets in Historic Center
activities.description: Explore the charming evening artisan markets that take place throughout summer in Montpellier's historic squares, featuring local craftspeople, artists, and food producers.
activities.seasonal_notes: These markets provide a festive atmosphere during warm summer evenings, with different neighborhoods hosting them on rotating nights of the week.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required. Check with the tourist office for the rotating schedule. The markets at Place de la Canourgue and Place Saint-Roch are particularly atmospheric.

activities.name: Cinéma sous les Étoiles
activities.description: Experience outdoor cinema screenings in historic locations throughout Montpellier, from the Peyrou gardens to museum courtyards and neighborhood squares.
activities.seasonal_notes: These open-air screenings run throughout July and August, beginning after sunset around 9:30pm with a mix of classic films and new releases.
activities.booking_tips: Some screenings require advance booking online, while others are free with first-come, first-served seating. Bring a cushion or blanket for comfort.

activities.name: Pézenas Historic Town
activities.description: Visit this exquisitely preserved medieval and Renaissance town associated with Molière, featuring artisan workshops, historic mansions, and a Saturday market in a theatrical setting.
activities.seasonal_notes: Summer brings this historic town to life with street performers, evening artisan markets, and courtyard concerts adding to the already rich architectural experience.
activities.booking_tips: Take the 603 bus from Montpellier (about 1 hour) or drive. For the full experience, visit on Saturday when the market fills the historic center.

activities.name: Sunset Drinks at Rooftop Bars
activities.description: Enjoy panoramic views of Montpellier while sipping cocktails at one of the city's popular rooftop bars, watching the sun set over the Mediterranean horizon.
activities.seasonal_notes: Summer evenings offer spectacular sunset views and pleasant temperatures for outdoor drinking until late into the night.
activities.booking_tips: Reserve tables in advance at popular spots like the Hôtel Mercure Centre rooftop or Chez Régis at the top of Saint-Roch hospital. Arrive before sunset for the best experience.

activities.name: Les Internationales de la Guitare
activities.description: Experience this renowned guitar festival featuring diverse styles from classical to flamenco, jazz to rock, with performances by international artists in venues throughout Montpellier and surrounding towns.
activities.seasonal_notes: This late September to early October festival brings world-class guitarists to the region when the weather turns cooler but remains pleasant for evening outings.
activities.booking_tips: Book tickets for main concerts well in advance through the festival website. Some masterclasses and small venue concerts are available for last-minute bookings.

activities.name: Harvest Time in Vineyards
activities.description: Visit the vineyards around Montpellier during grape harvest season (vendange) when the countryside buzzes with activity and many domains offer special tastings of young wines.
activities.seasonal_notes: September and early October bring the excitement of harvest to vineyards throughout the region, with excellent opportunities to understand winemaking processes.
activities.booking_tips: Book vineyard tours through the Montpellier tourist office or contact wineries directly in appellations like Pic Saint-Loup, Languedoc, or Grés de Montpellier.

activities.name: Mushroom Foraging in Cévennes
activities.description: Join guided mushroom hunting expeditions in the nearby Cévennes mountains when autumn rains bring forth prized varieties like cèpes, chanterelles, and many other edible fungi.
activities.seasonal_notes: October and November offer the best mushroom hunting after rainfall, with expert guides ensuring you collect only safe, edible varieties in sustainable ways.
activities.booking_tips: Book guided foraging trips through specialists like Cévennes Mycologie at least two weeks in advance. Tours typically include identification lessons and cooking tips.

activities.name: CineMed Film Festival
activities.description: Immerse yourself in Mediterranean cinema at this international film festival showcasing works from countries bordering the Mediterranean Sea, with screenings, director talks, and cultural events.
activities.seasonal_notes: This October/November festival brings together filmmakers from Southern Europe, North Africa, and the Middle East during the comfortable autumn season.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase festival passes online or individual screening tickets at the Corum and participating cinemas. Some director talks and workshops are free but require registration.

activities.name: Hiking in Hortus Mountains
activities.description: Explore the spectacular limestone landscapes of the Hortus and Pic Saint-Loup mountains when autumn brings clear visibility, comfortable temperatures, and beautiful golden light.
activities.seasonal_notes: Autumn offers ideal hiking conditions with moderate temperatures, seasonal colors in the vegetation, and fewer hikers than spring or summer months.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required for self-guided hikes. Maps are available at the tourist office or download the Visorando app for detailed trail information. The 'Sentier du Panorama' offers particularly spectacular views.

activities.name: Olive Harvest Experience
activities.description: Participate in the traditional olive harvest at farms around Montpellier, learning about cultivation methods and oil production before tasting the region's liquid gold.
activities.seasonal_notes: November and early December bring the olive harvest season, when you can witness the production of new oil and participate in picking at some domains.
activities.booking_tips: Book harvest experiences through the Olive Growing Museum in Clermont l'Hérault or contact producers like Domaine de l'Oulivie directly for tour and tasting appointments.

activities.name: Autumn Food Markets
activities.description: Explore Montpellier's vibrant food markets showcasing autumn specialties like wild mushrooms, chestnuts, game, and the first pressing of olive oil.
activities.seasonal_notes: Autumn brings an abundance of seasonal delicacies to the covered market at Les Halles Castellane and the open-air markets at Arceaux and Plan Cabanes.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required. Visit Les Halles Castellane Tuesday through Sunday mornings, Arceaux market on Tuesday and Saturday mornings, and Plan Cabanes on Tuesday through Saturday mornings.

activities.name: Contemporary Art at MOCO
activities.description: Discover Montpellier's contemporary art center housed in a renovated 18th-century mansion, featuring autumn exhibitions by international artists as part of the post-summer cultural calendar.
activities.seasonal_notes: Fall exhibitions typically open in September and run through December in this elegant setting that combines historic architecture with cutting-edge art.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required. The center is closed on Mondays and offers free guided tours on Sunday afternoons. Combined tickets with La Panacée (the center's other venue) are available.

activities.name: Chestnut Festival in Cévennes
activities.description: Experience the traditional chestnut harvest celebration in picturesque Cévennes mountain villages, with tastings, demonstrations, and cultural events dedicated to this historic staple food.
activities.seasonal_notes: October brings these festivals to villages like Saint-Martial and Olargues, celebrating the chestnut harvest that has sustained mountain communities for centuries.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required for festival entry, but accommodation in the small villages fills quickly. Drive from Montpellier (about 1.5 hours) or take a combination of train and bus to reach the Cévennes villages.

activities.name: Les Hivernales Christmas Market
activities.description: Wander through Montpellier's charming Christmas market centered around the Esplanade Charles de Gaulle and Place de la Comédie, with wooden chalets selling crafts, regional foods, and mulled wine.
activities.seasonal_notes: From late November through December, the market creates a festive atmosphere with lights, decorations, and seasonal treats including local specialties.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required. Visit weekday evenings to avoid weekend crowds. The illuminations and Ferris wheel in Place de la Comédie add to the festive atmosphere.

activities.name: Truffle Markets
activities.description: Experience the mysterious world of the black diamond of cuisine at specialized truffle markets in villages around Montpellier, where hunters sell their precious fungi directly to the public.
activities.seasonal_notes: December through February is truffle season in the Languedoc, with special markets in villages like Uzès and Saint-Geniès-des-Mourgues offering this prized winter delicacy.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required for market entry, but arrive early (before 10am) for the best selection. Some markets offer truffle-hunting demonstrations and cooking workshops that should be booked in advance.

activities.name: Wine Tasting by the Fireplace
activities.description: Escape winter chill with cozy wine tastings in historic cellars and tasting rooms around Montpellier, focusing on the robust red wines that perfectly complement the season.
activities.seasonal_notes: Winter is perfect for discovering the region's fuller-bodied reds from appellations like Saint-Chinian, Faugères, and Terrasses du Larzac in warm, comfortable settings.
activities.booking_tips: Book guided tastings at La Maison des Vins du Languedoc in central Montpellier or arrange visits to nearby wineries that offer fireside tastings during winter months.

activities.name: Opera at Le Corum
activities.description: Attend an opera, classical concert, or ballet at Montpellier's impressive Corum concert hall, home to the National Orchestra of Montpellier and a prestigious winter performance season.
activities.seasonal_notes: The winter season features both classic productions and innovative performances in this acoustically perfect modern venue.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase tickets through the Opera Orchestre National Montpellier website at least a month in advance. Pre-performance talks (in French) offer insights into the productions.

activities.name: Mont Aigoual Snow Experience
activities.description: Visit the highest point in the region, often snow-covered in winter, for sledding, cross-country skiing, or simply enjoying the rare snowy landscape just 90 minutes from Mediterranean Montpellier.
activities.seasonal_notes: December through February offers the best chance for snow at this 1,567m peak in the Cévennes National Park.
activities.booking_tips: Check snow conditions before departing. Drive yourself or take organized day trips from Montpellier. Equipment rental is available at the mountain station.

activities.name: Thermal Spa in Balaruc-les-Bains
activities.description: Indulge in therapeutic thermal waters at this historic spa town on the Thau Lagoon, with treatments harnessing the natural mineral-rich waters known since Roman times.
activities.seasonal_notes: Winter is ideal for warming thermal treatments, with fewer visitors than the high season and a peaceful atmosphere in this lakeside town.
activities.booking_tips: Reserve treatments at O'balia Spa or Thermes de Balaruc at least one week in advance. Day packages combining multiple treatments offer the best value.

activities.name: Indoor Food Markets
activities.description: Explore Les Halles Castellane, Montpellier's historic covered market, for winter specialties including oysters from nearby Bouzigues, regional cheeses, and seasonal game.
activities.seasonal_notes: Winter brings peak season for Mediterranean oysters, truffles, and hearty regional specialties perfect for the cooler weather.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required. Visit Tuesday through Sunday mornings, with the market closing around 2pm. Some oyster vendors offer on-site tasting with a glass of white wine.

activities.name: Winter Sales Shopping
activities.description: Take advantage of France's regulated winter sales season (soldes) with significant discounts in Montpellier's fashion boutiques, department stores, and the Polygone shopping center.
activities.seasonal_notes: The winter sales period typically runs from mid-January to mid-February, with the best selection available in the first weeks.
activities.booking_tips: No booking required. The Polygone mall and boutiques around Place de la Comédie offer the highest concentration of shopping options. Arrive early on the first day of sales for the best selection.

activities.name: FISE Indoor Extreme Sports
activities.description: Watch world-class skateboarders, BMX riders, and other extreme sports athletes compete in the indoor winter edition of Montpellier's famous FISE World Series event.
activities.seasonal_notes: This February event brings the energy of extreme sports indoors during the winter months, with competitions and demonstrations by top athletes.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase tickets online in advance for the main competition days. Some qualifying rounds and practice sessions are free to spectators.
